questions.title: Overview of Equity Securities
questions.question:
Which of the following statements is most accurate?

  1. Putable common shares provide benefits to both the issuing company and investors.
  2. Convertible preference shares are more volatile and riskier than the underlying common shares.
  3. Investors owning a small number of common shares would prefer statutory voting to cumulative voting.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. The put option feature facilitates raising capital because the shares are more appealing to investors. As such, it provides a benefit to the issuing company. It also helps investors limit their potential losses because they can sell the shares back to the issuing company if the market price falls below the pre-specified put price. Therefore, putable common shares are beneficial to both the issuing company and the investors. Incorrect. Convertible preference shares are less volatile and less risky than the underlying common shares because the dividend payments are known and more stable. Incorrect. Investors owning a small number of common shares would prefer cumulative voting, not statutory voting. Cumulative voting allows the investor to cast all votes in favor of a single candidate thereby increasing the chance of having her preferred candidate elected. Overview of Equity Securities describe characteristics of types of equity securities
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. The put option feature facilitates raising capital because the shares are more appealing to investors. As such, it provides a benefit to the issuing company. It also helps investors limit their potential losses because they can sell the shares back to the issuing company if the market price falls below the pre-specified put price. Therefore, putable common shares are beneficial to both the issuing company and the investors.

  2. Incorrect. Convertible preference shares are less volatile and less risky than the underlying common shares because the dividend payments are known and more stable.

  3. Incorrect. Investors owning a small number of common shares would prefer cumulative voting, not statutory voting. Cumulative voting allows the investor to cast all votes in favor of a single candidate thereby increasing the chance of having her preferred candidate elected.

questions.title: Overview of Equity Securities
questions.question:
Which of the following is most accurate concerning key characteristics of different types of preference shares?

  1. Preference shares have characteristics of both debt and equity securities.
  2. Preference shareholders rank above subordinated bondholders with respect to claims on the company’s net assets upon liquidation.
  3. The price of convertible preference shares tends to be more volatile than their underlying common shares because they do not allow investors to share in profits of the company.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. Preference shares have characteristics of both debt securities and common shares. Similar to interest payments on debt securities, the dividends on preference shares are fixed but not contractual obligations. Similar to common shares, preference shares can be perpetual and can pay dividends indefinitely. Incorrect. Both common and preference shareholders are owners of the company and will have claims on assets after liabilities to all creditors including bondholders have been completely paid. Preference shareholders rank before common shareholders but after bondholders to receive net distributions. Incorrect. The price of convertible preference shares is less volatile than their underlying common shares because there is less uncertainty about future cash flows as dividend payments are known and more stable. In addition, convertible preference shares allow investors the opportunity to share in the profits of the company. Overview of Equity Securities describe characteristics of types of equity securities
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. Preference shares have characteristics of both debt securities and common shares. Similar to interest payments on debt securities, the dividends on preference shares are fixed but not contractual obligations. Similar to common shares, preference shares can be perpetual and can pay dividends indefinitely.

  2. Incorrect. Both common and preference shareholders are owners of the company and will have claims on assets after liabilities to all creditors including bondholders have been completely paid. Preference shareholders rank before common shareholders but after bondholders to receive net distributions.

  3. Incorrect. The price of convertible preference shares is less volatile than their underlying common shares because there is less uncertainty about future cash flows as dividend payments are known and more stable. In addition, convertible preference shares allow investors the opportunity to share in the profits of the company.

Overview of Equity Securities

  • describe characteristics of types of equity securities

questions.question:
The advantages to an investor owning convertible preference shares of a company most likely include:

  1. less price volatility than the underlying common shares.
  2. preference dividends that are fixed contractual obligations of the company.
  3. an opportunity to receive additional dividends if the company’s profits exceed a pre-specified level.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. Convertible preference shares tend to exhibit less price volatility than the underlying common shares because the dividend payments are known and more stable. Incorrect. Preference dividends are fixed but, unlike interest payment on debt, they are not contractual obligations of the company. Incorrect. An opportunity to receive additional dividend if the company’s profits exceed a pre-specified level is the benefit that accrues to the holders of participating preferred shares, not convertible preference shareholders. questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. Convertible preference shares tend to exhibit less price volatility than the underlying common shares because the dividend payments are known and more stable.

  2. Incorrect. Preference dividends are fixed but, unlike interest payment on debt, they are not contractual obligations of the company.

  3. Incorrect. An opportunity to receive additional dividend if the company’s profits exceed a pre-specified level is the benefit that accrues to the holders of participating preferred shares, not convertible preference shareholders.

questions.question:
Participating preference shares are least likely to entitle the shareholders to participate in:

  1. corporate decisions through voting rights.
  2. additional distribution of the company’s assets upon liquidation.
  3. additional dividends if the company’s profits exceed a predetermined level.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. Participating preference shares do not entitle the shareholders to participate in corporate decisions through voting rights. But they do entitle them to (1) an additional dividend if the company’s profits exceed a prespecified level and (2) additional distribution of the company’s assets upon liquidation, above the par. Incorrect. Participating preference shares entitle the shareholders to participate in additional distribution of the company’s assets upon liquidation, above the par. Incorrect. Participating preference shares entitle the shareholders to participate in additional dividend if the company’s profits exceed a pre-specific level. Overview of Equity Securities describe differences in voting rights and other ownership characteristics among different equity classes
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. Participating preference shares do not entitle the shareholders to participate in corporate decisions through voting rights. But they do entitle them to (1) an additional dividend if the company’s profits exceed a prespecified level and (2) additional distribution of the company’s assets upon liquidation, above the par.

  2. Incorrect. Participating preference shares entitle the shareholders to participate in additional distribution of the company’s assets upon liquidation, above the par.

  3. Incorrect. Participating preference shares entitle the shareholders to participate in additional dividend if the company’s profits exceed a pre-specific level.

questions.title: Overview of Equity Securities
questions.question:
The type of voting in board elections that is most beneficial to shareholders with a small number of shares is best described as:

  1. statutory voting.
  2. voting by proxy.
  3. cumulative voting.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. In statutory voting, votes cannot be cast on a cumulative basis thereby making it disadvantageous to investors with small number of shares to elect their preferred candidate(s) to the board. Incorrect. Voting by proxy allows a designated party—such as another shareholder, a shareholder representative, or management—to vote on the shareholders’ behalf. By itself it does not provide a benefit to small investors in board elections. Correct. Cumulative voting allows shareholders to direct their total voting rights to specific candidates, as opposed to having to allocate their voting rights evenly among all candidates. Thus, applying all of the votes to one candidate provides the opportunity for a higher level of representation on the board than would be allowed under statutory voting. Overview of Equity Securities describe differences in voting rights and other ownership characteristics among different equity classes
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. In statutory voting, votes cannot be cast on a cumulative basis thereby making it disadvantageous to investors with small number of shares to elect their preferred candidate(s) to the board.

  2. Incorrect. Voting by proxy allows a designated party—such as another shareholder, a shareholder representative, or management—to vote on the shareholders’ behalf. By itself it does not provide a benefit to small investors in board elections.

  3. Correct. Cumulative voting allows shareholders to direct their total voting rights to specific candidates, as opposed to having to allocate their voting rights evenly among all candidates. Thus, applying all of the votes to one candidate provides the opportunity for a higher level of representation on the board than would be allowed under statutory voting.

  • describe differences in voting rights and other ownership characteristics among different equity classes

questions.question:
A company has issued only one class of common shares, and it does not pay dividends on them. It has also issued two types of non-cumulative preference shares: one that is putable and the other callable. Which of these securities will most likely offer the lowest expected return to the investor?

  1. Common shares
  2. Putable preference shares
  3. Callable preference shares
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Common shares are the most risky, whether or not dividend paying, and are likely to offer the highest expected return. Though these preference shares have non-cumulative dividend feature, preference shareholders will receive priority if the company is liquidated. Correct. Putable preference shares are less risky than their callable counterparts. They give the investor the option to put the shares back to the company. Because of the lower risk, they will provide a lower expected rate of return. Common shares are the most risky, whether or not they are dividend paying, and are likely to offer the highest expected return. Incorrect. Callable preference shares are more risky than their putable counterparts and so they are likely to offer higher expected returns than putable preference shares. Overview of Equity Securities describe differences in voting rights and other ownership characteristics among different equity classes
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. Common shares are the most risky, whether or not dividend paying, and are likely to offer the highest expected return. Though these preference shares have non-cumulative dividend feature, preference shareholders will receive priority if the company is liquidated.

  2. Correct. Putable preference shares are less risky than their callable counterparts. They give the investor the option to put the shares back to the company. Because of the lower risk, they will provide a lower expected rate of return. Common shares are the most risky, whether or not they are dividend paying, and are likely to offer the highest expected return.

  3. Incorrect. Callable preference shares are more risky than their putable counterparts and so they are likely to offer higher expected returns than putable preference shares.

For a US investor, which of the following statements concerning investing in depository receipts (DRs) is least accurate?

Solution

  1. Incorrect because it is an accurate statement. The DRs trading on multiple exchanges could experience short-term valuation discrepancies, potentially giving rise to a quick arbitrage profit opportunity for astute traders to exploit. The price of each DR will be affected by factors that affect the price of the underlying shares and exchange rate movements.

  2. Incorrect because it is an accurate statement. Sponsored DRs are subject to greater reporting requirements than unsponsored DRs. In the United States, sponsored DRs must be registered with the SEC.

questions.title: Overview of Equity Securities
questions.question:
Calculate the return on equity (ROE) of a stable company using the following data:

Total sales £2,500,000
Net income £2,000,000
Beginning of year total assets £50,000,000
Beginning of year total liabilities £35,000,000
Number of shares outstanding at the end of the year 1,000,000
Price per share at the end of the year £20
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. A company’s ROE is calculated as (NI t /BVE t –1 ). The BVE t –1 is equal to the beginning total assets minus the beginning total liabilities, which equals £50,000,000 – £35,000,000 = £15,000,000. Therefore, ROE = £2,000,000/£15,000,000 = 13.3%.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. A company’s ROE is calculated as (NIt/BVEt–1). The BVEt–1 is equal to the beginning total assets minus the beginning total liabilities, which equals £50,000,000 – £35,000,000 = £15,000,000. Therefore, ROE = £2,000,000/£15,000,000 = 13.3%.

questions.title: Overview of Equity Securities
questions.question: Which of the following measures is the most difficult to estimate?

choices.A: The cost of debt.
choices.B: The cost of equity.
choices.C: Investors’ required rate of return on debt.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The cost of equity is not easily determined. It is dependent on investors’ required rate of return on equity, which reflects the different risk levels of investors and their expectations about the company’s future cash flows.

questions.title: Overview of Equity Securities
questions.question: A company’s cost of equity is often used as a proxy for investors’:

choices.A: average required rate of return.
choices.B: minimum required rate of return.
choices.C: maximum required rate of return.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Companies try to raise funds at the lowest possible cost. Therefore, cost of equity is used as a proxy for the minimum required rate of return.
